newsitem.title: GEORGIA: Georgia, EU sign cooperation pact.
newsitem.headline: Georgia, EU sign cooperation pact.

text.p: The European Union and the former Soviet republic of Georgia signed an interim agreement on Saturday aimed at encouraging economic ties.
The document, the first overall trade agreement between the EU and Georgia, includes sections on trade in goods, intellectual property, and customs matters.
It reiterates principles on human rights and democracy contained in a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) signed in April between the EU and Georgia.
"This is an important milestone on our road to European integration," President Eduard Shevardnadze said.
Foreign Minister Irakli Menagarishvili signed the 10-page document with Sean Farrell, Irish representative of the EU's rotating presidency.

Francois Lamoureux, head of the 15-member EU delegation, said it had talks with the government on a 2 million Ecu ($2.5 million) assistance package designed to help Georgia prepare to join the World Trade Organisation (WTO).
He said it was vital for the small Caucasus country to join the WTO before strong trade links could develop with the EU.
"We want Georgia to become a member of the WTO. Membership in the WTO will make Georgia a worthy economic partner for the members of the European Union," Lamoureux said.
Earlier in the week, the delegation signed a similar agreement with Azerbaijan.

Fokion Fotiadis, head of the EU's Transcaucasus, Central Asia and Mongolia department, said the delegation cancelled a trip to Armenia over "security concerns" in the wake of violence and political unrest after a controversial election there.
"We have insufficient security gurantees in view of the present situation in Armenia," he said.

He declined to answer when asked if the decision not to go to Yerevan was a form of protest over last month's reelection of President Levon Ter-Petrosyan, which international observers said was marked by voting irregularities.
"The chairman of our delegation has made the decision not to go there because of security matters," he said.

Ter-Petrosyan sent tanks into the streets and arrested as many as 250 political opponents after violent clashes between protesters who alleged he rigged the September 22 election which gave him a second five-year term.
The Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe said the irregularities may call into question his victory. ($1=.8012 Ecu)
